Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Linear Ion Trap Mass Spectrometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program and the Chemistry Division, Alexandra C. Stenson and colleagues Norris W. Hoffman, James H. Davis and Scott A. Miller from University of South Alabama will acquire an ion trap mass spectrometer. The instrument will enhance research efforts: a) to make in-roads in the structural characterization of natural compounds of geo and marine chemical importance, b) to improve and enhance CO2 capture by ionic liquids, c) to develop expanded passenger- and cargo-screening capabilities for explosives, d) to determine the original use for ancient pottery through analysis of organic residues left behind, e) to improve current synthetic catalysts and develop new ones, f) to develop/lay the groundwork for new pharmaceutical scaffolds, g) to aid the regulation of insect lures and traps for agricultural use, and, h) to improve selectivity in common HPLC columns and/or enhance the predictability of this selectivity.

Mass spectrometers (MS) are used to identify the chemical composition of a sample by measuring the mass of the molecular constituents in the sample after they are ionized and detected by the mass spectrometer. The ion trap is a particular design for the mass analyzer that separates the ions for subsequent identification at the detector. Undergraduates in several departments at the University will be trained in this widely employed analysis technique as they use it in their research projects and in laboratory courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research: Acquisition of this has instrument supported a diverse set of chemistry research projects including development of lower cost, more environmentally sustainable catalysts for a healthy chemical industry, research into converting chitin from seafood shells into new feedstocks for polymers, and the structural characterization of natural organic matter, which may serve as an invaluable scaffold source for new low-toxicity pharmaceuticals. In addition, the instrument has served (and is serving) in research projects that investigate anthropological history, global climate dependence on marine sulfur compounds, and drinking water safety.

Collaboration: Academic specialization and compartmentalization are among the largest hurdles standing in the way of solving truly complex real-world scientific problems. The instrument acquired through this grant has allowed for the bringing-together of different disciplines (e.g., analytical, organic, and inorganic chemistry), departments (i.e., chemistry, engineering, marine sciences, and archaeology) and even universities (i.e., University of South Alabama, Florida State University, and Florida Gulf Coast University) in collaborative research. More importantly, it has provided an avenue for students to gain education and technical training in a collaborative environment which will hopefully embolden them to think outside division lines when they embark on their own careers.

Training & Education: All research projects involving the instrument acquired through this grant have involved undergraduate researchers as hands-on users of the equipment. As such, students had a chance to gain proficiency with state-of-the art analytical technology and begin to understand the capabilities and limitations of chemical separations and mass spectral detection. In addition, the instrument was also incorporated into upper level laboratory courses. Combined, these efforts assured that few, if any, chemistry majors graduating from the Department of Chemistry did not have at least some contact with the instrument.

Shift in Attitudes towards Mass Spectrometry: Incorporation of the instrument into the Department’s infrastructure is slowly but surely leading to a transition in attitudes about the value and information content of mass spectral data. In the past, the overwhelming attitude among synthetic chemists has been that mass spectrometry provides no information other than the mass of an analyte. Furthermore, the vast majority of organic chemists considers only hard ionization methods such as electron impact mass spectrometry and have no concept of the quality and usefulness of soft-ionization mass spectral data. Through the incorporation of the instrument acquired through this grant into most research projects within the Department, faculty and students alike are awakened to the power of mass spectral data including tandem mass spectrometry, hydrogen-deuterium exchange, combination of chromatographic information with mass spectral data, and information contained in isotopic distributions. It is difficult to overstate the importance of connecting all research efforts with the most relevant state of the art analytical techniques available.
